instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00244: What is 820-00244? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PP3V3R3V0_AON: What is PP3V3R3V0_AON? PP3V3R3V0_AON is the first power rail you need to get a USB-C charger to go from 5v to 20v on an A1534 Macbook with an 820-00045 board..
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.SMC_BC_ACOK: What is SMC_BC_ACOK? This is identical to CHGR_ACOK. This will come out of the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging chip when CHGR_ACIN & CHGR_DCIN are present, and is necessary for the onewire circuit to begin working. On most Macbooks, CHGR_ACOK needs to be present in order for PP3V42_G3H to flow to the onewire circuit so that the circuitry that allows the charger to communicate with the SMC will turn on.  .
definitions.PP3V3_S5_SMC_VDDA: What is PP3V3_S5_SMC_VDDA? PP3V3_S5_SMC_VDDA is a 3.3v power rail present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state that powers the SMC that comes from PP3V3_S5. A blown or corroded L4901 inductor behind it can kepe it from working, inductor number will differ depending on your board. .
definitions.PP5V_G3H: What is PP5V_G3H? PP5V_G3H is a 5v rail present when the machine is in a G3H mechanical off state.
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> DC-in 5V PPBUS present tho
threads.message:
No liquid.

Replaced <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> (<CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>).
Didn't help. Same behaviour still.

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>: 8,19V

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>: 3,3V

<SIGNAL>PP3V3R3V0_AON</SIGNAL>: 3,3V


Ideas?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> DC-in 5V PPBUS present tho
threads.message:
Did you have same <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> voltage before replacing <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chip?
Did you solder same code termination?

What about <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>/SUS?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> DC-in 5V PPBUS present tho
threads.message:
Yes, I had the same <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> voltage also prior to changing the <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>.

The original was CD3215B01,

replaced it with ..B03.


<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL>: 3,3V

<SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> etc: 0V.

Enable pin 21 of <CHIP>U7650</CHIP> is at 0,8V...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> DC-in 5V PPBUS present tho
threads.message:
No idea if B01 is compatible with B03; maybe someone else can confirm that.

You could have a problem with SMC.
Check first for short on big coils.
Post <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> voltage.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> DC-in 5V PPBUS present tho
threads.message:
No shorts anywhere as far as I can tell.

<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL>: a few mill's at most. So I'd say 0V.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> DC-in 5V PPBUS present tho
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> DC-in 5V PPBUS present tho
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL>: 3,3V

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_SMC_VDDA</SIGNAL>: 3,3V

<SIGNAL>PP3V0_S5_AVREF_SMC</SIGNAL>: 3V

<SIGNAL>PP1V2_S5_SMC_VDDC</SIGNAL>: 1,2V

Would this mean that the SMC is faulty? Is that normal on these boards?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> DC-in 5V PPBUS present tho
threads.message:
Voltages look OK, but cannot discard SMC.

Check <SIGNAL>PP3V3_PMICLDO</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP1V25_PMICVREF</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP5V_G3H</SIGNAL>.
If no volt, check diode mode to ground.
<CHIP>U7800</CHIP> is suspect too...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> DC-in 5V PPBUS present tho
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_PMICLDO</SIGNAL>: 3,3v

<SIGNAL>PP1V25_PMICVREF</SIGNAL>: 1,2v

<SIGNAL>PP5V_G3H</SIGNAL>: 4,999v


EDIT: Tried another battery with (maybe) some juice left.

DC-in 20V, but doesn't charge.
Would this tell us that the SMC would be good after all?
What about <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> DC-in 5V PPBUS present tho
threads.message: <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> can be caused by SMC issue, or maybe B03 is not compatible with B01 for <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> DC-in 5V PPBUS present tho
threads.message: Is <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> needed for charging the battery?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> DC-in 5V PPBUS present tho
threads.message:
Is mandatory signnal to start the board with charger.
Check if battery is charging in your case...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> DC-in 5V PPBUS present tho
threads.message:
I actually wrote, that it doesn't charge with the other battery...
And obviously not with the original either.

It seems that a battery with juice is powering something to enable 20V for DC-in...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> DC-in 5V PPBUS present tho
threads.message:
Machine doesn't need a battery to get 20V from charger.
It can works with only 5V from USB port, available from other device (not charger).
SMC must talk with anything connected to USB port to recognize what is.
Looks like charger is not properly recognized in your case; because of charger, SMC, or other internal issue.
Did you try another charger?
